user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of lfs_file_sync:
```c
int lfs_file_sync(lfs_t *lfs, lfs_file_t *file) {
    int err = LFS_LOCK(lfs->cfg);
    if (err) {
        return err;
    }
    LFS_TRACE("lfs_file_sync(%p, %p)", (void*)lfs, (void*)file);
    LFS_ASSERT(lfs_mlist_isopen(lfs->mlist, (struct lfs_mlist*)file));

    err = lfs_file_sync_(lfs, file);

    LFS_TRACE("lfs_file_sync -> %d", err);
    LFS_UNLOCK(lfs->cfg);
    return err;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function lfs_file_sync:
#define LFS_LOCK(cfg) ((void)cfg,0)
...
#define LFS_UNLOCK(cfg) ((void)cfg)
...
#define LFS_TRACE(__VA_ARGS__) 
...
#define LFS_ASSERT(test) assert(test)
...
static bool lfs_mlist_isopen(struct lfs_mlist *head,
        struct lfs_mlist *node) {
    for (struct lfs_mlist **p = &head; *p; p = &(*p)->next) {
        if (*p == (struct lfs_mlist*)node) {
            return true;
        }
    }

    return false;
}
...
static int lfs_file_sync_(lfs_t *lfs, lfs_file_t *file) {
    if (file->flags & LFS_F_ERRED) {
        // it's not safe to do anything if our file errored
        return 0;
    }

    int err = lfs_file_flush(lfs, file);
    if (err) {
        file->flags |= LFS_F_ERRED;
        return err;
    }


    if ((file->flags & LFS_F_DIRTY) &&
            !lfs_pair_isnull(file->m.pair)) {
        // before we commit metadata, we need sync the disk to make sure
        // data writes don't complete after metadata writes
        if (!(file->flags & LFS_F_INLINE)) {
            err = lfs_bd_sync(lfs, &lfs->pcache, &lfs->rcache, false);
            if (err) {
                return err;
            }
        }

        // update dir entry
        uint16_t type;
        const void *buffer;
        lfs_size_t size;
        struct lfs_ctz ctz;
        if (file->flags & LFS_F_INLINE) {
            // inline the whole file
            type = LFS_TYPE_INLINESTRUCT;
            buffer = file->cache.buffer;
            size = file->ctz.size;
        } else {
            // update the ctz reference
            type = LFS_TYPE_CTZSTRUCT;
            // copy ctz so alloc will work during a relocate
            ctz = file->ctz;
            lfs_ctz_tole32(&ctz);
            buffer = &ctz;
            size = sizeof(ctz);
        }

        // commit file data and attributes
        err = lfs_dir_commit(lfs, &file->m, LFS_MKATTRS(
                {LFS_MKTAG(type, file->id, size), buffer},
                {LFS_MKTAG(LFS_FROM_USERATTRS, file->id,
                    file->cfg->attr_count), file->cfg->attrs}));
        if (err) {
            file->flags |= LFS_F_ERRED;
            return err;
        }

        file->flags &= ~LFS_F_DIRTY;
    }

    return 0;
}
...
typedef struct lfs {
    lfs_cache_t rcache;
    lfs_cache_t pcache;

    lfs_block_t root[2];
    struct lfs_mlist {
        struct lfs_mlist *next;
        uint16_t id;
        uint8_t type;
        lfs_mdir_t m;
    } *mlist;
    uint32_t seed;

    lfs_gstate_t gstate;
    lfs_gstate_t gdisk;
    lfs_gstate_t gdelta;

    struct lfs_lookahead {
        lfs_block_t start;
        lfs_block_t size;
        lfs_block_t next;
        lfs_block_t ckpoint;
        uint8_t *buffer;
    } lookahead;

    const struct lfs_config *cfg;
    lfs_size_t block_count;
    lfs_size_t name_max;
    lfs_size_t file_max;
    lfs_size_t attr_max;
    lfs_size_t inline_max;

#ifdef LFS_MIGRATE
    struct lfs1 *lfs1;
#endif
} lfs_t
...
typedef struct lfs_file {
    struct lfs_file *next;
    uint16_t id;
    uint8_t type;
    lfs_mdir_t m;

    struct lfs_ctz {
        lfs_block_t head;
        lfs_size_t size;
    } ctz;

    uint32_t flags;
    lfs_off_t pos;
    lfs_block_t block;
    lfs_off_t off;
    lfs_cache_t cache;

    const struct lfs_file_config *cfg;
} lfs_file_t
...
struct lfs_mlist {
        struct lfs_mlist *next;
        uint16_t id;
        uint8_t type;
        lfs_mdir_t m;
    }
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I inspected the provided functions and related symbols for any modifications of function parameters (assignments to the parameter variables themselves, e.g. lfs = ..., file = ..., head = ..., or increments/decrements). None were found.

Details supporting this conclusion:
- lfs_file_sync: uses parameters lfs and file only as arguments to other functions/macros and for assertions; there is no assignment to the parameters themselves.
- lfs_file_sync_: modifies members of *file (e.g. file->flags), which is permitted by MISRA Rule 17.8 (the object pointed to by a pointer parameter may be modified). There are no assignments to the parameter variable file or lfs themselves.
- lfs_mlist_isopen: the code takes &head to iterate via a struct lfs_mlist **p, but it never assigns to head (or *p). The loop traverses the list by reading next pointers; this does not modify the head parameter variable.
- Macros (LFS_LOCK, LFS_UNLOCK, LFS_TRACE, LFS_ASSERT) either expand to void casts or use parameters only as values; they do not perform assignments that would modify the parameter variables.

Therefore there are no fragments that warrant investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8.
